front: What does Dr. Winston W. Royce mean are the two essential steps common to all computer program developments, regardless of size or complexity?
back: An analysis step following second by a coding step.

front: What is a linear-sequential life cycle model also reffered to as?&nbsp
back: The waterfall model

front: What was the first process model to be introduced?
back: The waterfall model

front: In a waterfall model, what must happen before the next phase can begin?
back: The previous phase must be completed fully.

front: What type of projects is the waterfall model used for?
back: Projects which are small and there are no uncertain requirements

front: In the waterfall model, what is considered at the end of each phase?
back: A review to determine whether the project is on the right path and whether or not to continue or discard the project.

front: In the waterfall model, do phases overlap?
back: No, they do not overlap.

front: In the waterfall model, when does software testing start?
back: After the development is complete.

front: When did the waterfall model stop being used (primarily)?
back: It stopped in the year 2000. Even after the Agile manifesto was published in 2001, Waterfall model continued to be used by many organizations till the last decade.

front: In the olden days, application developed in Waterfall Model would usually take how long to develop?
back: A year or longer

front: Using the waterfall method, why is it very expensive if a failure occurs?
back: Because we need to update everything from document till the logic.

front: What does the V-model mean?
back: Verification and validation model.

front: In the V-model what must happen in the previous phase before the next phase begins?
back: The previous phase must be completed.

front: Who is credited with having invented the waterfall method?
back: Dr Winston W. Royce

front: How deep does the system design phase go in the waterfall method?
back: In theory, all the way down to the design of the classes and functions.

front: What is MOSCOW when talking about priority?
back: Must have, should have, could have, won’t have

front: What is the difference between a functional requirement and a non-functional requirement?
back: A functional requirement is something that the user can do, e.g. login, change name etc., A non-functional requirement is on the entire system, e.g. having 99% uptime, having good enough speed etc.

front: What is UAT?
back: User acceptance testing, seeing whether the users accept the project or not

front: Did Dr. Winston W. Royce invent the waterfall model?
back: No, he made a paper about it, describing what he observed.

front: What are the 5 domains of the Cynefin complexity model?
back: Obvious, complicated, complex, chaotic and disorder.

front: What is the literal translation of Cynefin?
back: 'habitat’ or ‘place’, from Welsh. Actual meaning: place of multiple belongings; cultural, religious, geographic, tribal etc.

front: Which domain in Cynefin are we in most of the time?
back: Disorder, the domain where we do not know which other domain we’re in.

front: Is Agile development process-based?
back: No, it is not.

front: Agile methods derive much of their agility by what?
back: Relying on the tacit (implicit) knowledge knowledge embodied in the team, rather than writing the knowledge down in plans.

front: What do the requirements have to be for plan-driven methods to work best?
back: Relatively stable, with change rates on the order of one percent per month.

front: In Cynefin, what are systems on the right side described as?
back: Ordered, meaning cause and effect are predictable.

front: In Cynefin, what are systems on the left side described as?
back: Unordered, meaning cause and effect are unpredictable

front: How many documentation documents does Royce propose to use?
back: To quote: “Quite a lot”

front: Why is the border between simple and chaotic different than the others?
back: Believing you’re in the simple zone might lead you to become overconfident and slide into the chaotic zone. This is why it is often described as a cliff or wave.

front: What is simple also called in other versions of Cynefin?
back: Obvious or Clear

front: Scrum is founded on empiricism, which asserts what?
back: That knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is observed.

front: Scrum is founded on lean thinking, which does what?
back: Reduces waste and focuses on the essentials.

front: Successful use of Scrum depends on people becoming more proficient in living which five values?
back: Commitment, focus, openness, respect and courage.

front: Who manages the scrum team?
back: Themselves, they internally decide who does what, when and how.

front: What is a sprint in scrum?
back: A sprint is a short, time-boxed period when a scrum team works to complete a set amount of work.

front: How large is a scrum team generally?
back: 3-9 people, but can be larger or smaller.

front: What should scrum teams do if they become too big?
back: Reorganizing into multiple cohesive Scrum Teams, each focused on the same product.

front: In Scrum, who is responsible for all product-related activies?
back: The Scrum team. This includes stakeholder collaboration, verification, maintenance, operation, experimentation, research and development.

front:
In Scrum, who is responsible for the following?
  • Creating a plan for the Sprint, the Sprint Backlog
  • Instilling quality by adhering to a Definition of Done
  • Adapting their plan each day toward the Sprint Goal, and
  • Holding each other accountable as professionals.
back: The developers.

front: Who is accountable for maximizing the value of the product resulting from the work of the Scrum Team?
back: The product owner.

front: Who establishes scrum as defined in the scrum guide?
back: The scrum master.

front: In scrum, who is responsible for leading, training and coaching the organization in its Scrum adoption?
back: The scrum master.

front: In scrum, who is responsible for helping the scrum team understand the need for clear and concise product backlog items?
back: The scrum master.

front: How long are sprints in Scrum?
back: Fixed length of one month or less.

front: When does a new sprint begin in Scrum?
back: Immediately after the conclusion of the previous sprint.

front: In Scrum, which topics are addressed during sprint planning?
back: Why the Sprint is valuable, what can be Done this Sprint and How will the chosen work get done?

front: What is Daily Scrum?
back: A 15-minute event for the Developers of the Scrum team, which focuses on progress toward the Sprint Goal and produces and actionable plan for the next day of work.

front: What is the purpose of the Sprint Retrospective in Scrum?
back: To plan ways to increase quality and effectiveness.

front: What is the product backlog in Scrum?
back: An emergent, ordered list of what is needed to improve the product.

front: What is the Sprint Backlog composed of in Scrum?
back: The Sprint Goal (why), the set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint (what), as well as an actionable plan for delivering the Increment (how)

front: What is an Increment in Scrum?
back: A concrete stepping stone toward the Product Goal.

front: What happens when a Product Backlog item meets the definition of Done in Scrum?
back: An Increment is born.

front: What is MVP short for?
back: Minimum viable product

front: Who uses the MVP version of a product?
back: Early customers who can then provide feedback for future product development

front: What is Big Bang delivery?
back: Building the thing until 100% done, and delivering at the end.

front: What is Earlist Testable Product also called?
back: Minimum Viable Product, MVP
